original.definition: leave or give by will after one's death

sememes.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is to 'leave or give', which describes a transfer of ownership, hence a change in possession.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' who initiates the transfer by making a will. This is the grantor.
The 'something' whose possession is transferred, typically an inheritance or legacy.
The 'somebody' who receives the bequeathed item, usually a beneficiary.

sememes.reasoning: The transfer is specifically carried out 'by will', indicating a legal document as the instrument of transfer, a core distinguishing feature of 'bequeath'.
The definition states 'after one's death', indicating that the actual transfer of possession takes effect subsequent to the bequeather's demise, which is a critical temporal condition.

Evidentiality.reasoning: The act of bequeathing (e.g., creating a will) is typically a documented and directly verifiable event.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's primary use is to state a fact about a transfer of property.

Modality.reasoning: The act of bequeathing 'by will' is a deliberate and intentional action by the agent, indicating strong will.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of bequeathing itself is neutral; its sentiment depends on the context and the nature of the legacy.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody bequeath...' explicitly denotes a volitional agent performing an intentional act of giving through a will.

Confidence.reasoning: The verb describes a definite act of transferring property.

Iterativity.reasoning: The act of bequeathing a specific item or estate is generally considered a single, distinct event, even if a will can be changed.

sememes.reasoning: verb_property 'event_time.n.01' is not a valid synset in NLTK.

candidates.description: performing a role in an event that occurred at an earlier time (gloss match)
counting backward from an arbitrary number to indicate the time remaining before some event (such as launching a space vehicle) (gloss match)
setting an order and time for planned events (gloss match)
(computer science) a moving design that appears on a computer screen when there has been no input for a specified period of time (gloss match)
chronoscope for measuring the time difference between two events (gloss match)
arrangement of events in time (gloss match)
loss of memory for events immediately following a trauma; sometimes in effect for events during and for a long time following the trauma (gloss match)
a philosophical doctrine holding that all events are predetermined in advance for all time and human beings are powerless to change them (gloss match)
the four-dimensional coordinate system (3 dimensions of space and 1 of time) in which physical events are located (gloss match)

a Gestalt principle of organization holding that (other things being equal) objects or events that are near to one another (in space or time) are perceived as belonging together as a unit (gloss match)
a schedule listing events and the times at which they will take place (gloss match)
an event or situation that happens at the same time as or in connection with another (gloss match)
an instance or single occasion for some event (gloss match)
an event that occurs at a critical time (gloss match)
operations that occur without a regular or predictable time relation to other events (gloss match)
(epidemiology) the ratio (for a given time period) of the number of occurrences of a disease or event to the number of units at risk in the population (gloss match)
an arrangement of events in time (gloss match)
a problematic situation that will eventually become dangerous if not addressed (gloss match)
the aggregate of past events (gloss match)
the coordinated universal time when an event is received on Earth (gloss match)
the time that elapses while some event is occurring (gloss match)
an arrangement of events used as a measure of duration (gloss match)
the time of a particular event (gloss match)
the time between one event, process, or period and another (gloss match)
the time between occurrences of a repeating event (gloss match)
any distinct time period in a sequence of events (gloss match)

sememes.corrected_reasoning: Candidate 'occasion.n.04' ('the time of a particular event') is a perfect semantic and contextual replacement for the invalid 'event_time.n.01'.
